item.title: By: Nitin
item.dc:creator: Nitin
item.description: You could get in touch with these guys at some point: http://www.siyavula.com I've volunteered on checking their maths and physics high-school textbooks (in English) at some point, and they might be able to give you some ideas that might be interesting to you. I think you probably need to do a survey about the demographics of the incoming class over the past few years, and decide which translations you should focus on (I think you will have to sacrifice a few languages at the start). Start a few and do it well. The video idea is great! I think all classes should definitely adopt this video intro/testimonial aspect, and having a mix of students, tutors and faculty/teaching staff saying positive things about a course would go some way to giving some overall insight. All the best with your experiments, and this year's teaching, Jon! :)
item.content:encoded:
You could get in touch with these guys at some point: http://www.siyavula.com
I’ve volunteered on checking their maths and physics high-school textbooks (in English) at some point, and they might be able to give you some ideas that might be interesting to you.
I think you probably need to do a survey about the demographics of the incoming class over the past few years, and decide which translations you should focus on (I think you will have to sacrifice a few languages at the start). Start a few and do it well.
The video idea is great! I think all classes should definitely adopt this video intro/testimonial aspect, and having a mix of students, tutors and faculty/teaching staff saying positive things about a course would go some way to giving some overall insight.
All the best with your experiments, and this year’s teaching, Jon!

item.title: By: Jonathan Shock
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Shock
item.description:
Hi Caro, great comments. Indeed I contacted the African Languages and literature department but was worried because I don't have funding for this and don't want to exploit anyone. They put me in contact (via a couple of hops) with http://www.mep.uct.ac.za/ the multilingual education program, who do have resources for exactly this sort of project. The meeting with them was really positive! It seems that they go to a number of translation agencies, most of which seem to have former UCT graduates. I spoke with them and we discussed some very exciting possibilities regarding creating glossaries of technical terminology specific to this course which could be done collaboratively between MEP and the students taking the course to help bolster understanding. This is all very experimental from my point of view, but it seems that we need to try different avenues for increasing inclusiveness.
The mentors come from a pretty big range of different linguistic backgrounds, and so they will definitely be in the call for video making, but I will make it wider, to all 700 or so students who started on last year's MAM1000 course. In my experience, I have had trouble in getting many people to take part in these sorts of things, which is why I am really interested in more ideas from students and those from other fields. The translation competitions I ran on here didn't get that many entries at all, and so it is clear that I'm doing something wrong with my approach.
Thanks again for the support :-)

item.title: By: Caro Le Tang
item.dc:creator: Caro Le Tang
item.description:
Hi, Dr Shock! Are the mentors that you mention perhaps not in the best position to help with the videos? Or are they monolingual English speakers? I imagine they have already been through the course so they might have some good ideas about how to make the handbook more accessible through the video format if they're bilingual. That said, I think the competition is a wonderful idea!
In terms of translation, I think it's going to be quite time consuming and I think you've already highlighted a very important consideration about first language speakers not always being able to read their mother tongue. I would suggest you contact the African Languages and Literature department to offer the translation work to their students (perhaps tutors or postgrads) so that you have at least one faithful translation per language and then perhaps rope those students in to help judge the competition?
I wish more lecturers were as committed to their teaching as you are. I look forward to reading more about this endeavour :)

item.title: By: Jonathan Shock
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Shock
item.description:
Hi Nicola, I will be asking those who have been through it before to make the videos. I think that it's important to come from people who have seen what MAM1000 is like and in particular I don't want to be asking people to do things like this who have just arrived at university for the first time and already are rather overwhelmed with the experience. If it were about the MAM1000 material itself then I think that it would be a useful exercise for current students, but because it's more about the general nature of the course, it's not something that I think people need to 'learn', but more take on board.
Does that make sense?
All the best,
Jonathan
